Ruby Werman

Highland Park, IL 60035 · (847) 404-0114 · rubywerman@berkeley.edu

I am computer science major at UC Berkeley passionate about technology and design. I'm interested in software engineering and product management roles with an emphasis on emerging technolgies. I'm part of the inagural class of MLH Fellows, a 2020 Birthright Israel Excel Business Fellow, and an Intel URP Scholar. At school I'm involved in computer science research, tutoring, consulting, and virtual reality. In my free time I like creating Instragram AR filters, which have received over 300,000 views. I love to travel and would love to work abroad at some point in college or afterwards!

Experience

MLH Fellow

Major League Hacking

Selected from over 20,000 applicants to be part of the inaugural class of 100 MLH Fellows powered by Github. Contribute to Open Source projects alongside a team of students and software engineers.

June 2020 - Present

Research Assistant

Goodly Labs

Participate in Berkeley's Undergraduate Research Apprentice Program (URAP) under Nobel Laureate Saul Perlmutter. Lead the development of a communtiy forum for Public Editor, a national-scale data science project that engages thousands of public volunteers and news readers.

January 2020 - Present

Research Intern

University of Chicago, Center for Data and Computing

Worked alongside RDCEP and Globus labs on cloud classification through deep learning. Designed and created Python application for labeling cloud images for a deep neural network. Created Python script to accelerate data acquisition from NASA's satellite data web interface. Researched and tested various unsupervised clustering algorithms. My team's work from the summer was featured at the American Geophysical Union's Fall 2019 Conference, as well as the The 9th International Workshop on Climate Informatics in Paris, France.

June 2019 - August 2019

Academic Intern

University of California, Berkeley, Department of Data Science

Assist students currently enrolled in Data 8 (The Foundations of Data Science) during Lab with labs, projects, and challenging concepts; topics include programming in python, statistical inference, and modeling of real-world datasets.

January 2019 - May 2019

Tutor

Computer Science Mentors

Lead 4-person adjunct sessions for CS 88 (Computational Structures in Data Science); topics covered include functional programming, data abstraction, and object-oriented programming in python.

January 2019 - May 2019

Graphic Designer

Self

Started small business creating custom stickers, graphics, and apparel with over 2,500 sales. Create custom AR filters for Instagram and Facebook with over 300,000 total impressions.

January 2018 - Present

Projects

Here's a selection of some of the projects I've worked on

Instagram Filters

Spark AR, Photoshop, Illustrator

I've created a variety of Instagram filters, including games, makeup/beauty, and promotional content. I work with influencers and universities to make custom filters for their pages, as well as feature filters on my personal account, @rubywerm

Equity- Ethical Information for a conscious consumer

Python, Javascript, HTML, css, beautiful-soup, json

Equity is a chrome extension for Amazon.com that provides ethical scores for products. The scores come from The Ethical Consumer, an independent, not-for-profit, co-operative, based in the United Kingdom. I worked on Equity with a small group for CalHacks 6.0

Crime in Chicago

Python, Pandas

I worked with a small group to create a deep learning model to model crime in Chicago using Amazon Sagemaker.

61B: The Video Game

JAVA

I worked with a partner to create a roguelike video game with a psuedo-random map generator and fun interface. We developed the game from scratch and even added in some easter eggs!

NumPy Dupe

C, Python, OpenMP, Intel AVX Intrinsics

I implemented a subset of the NumPy module using optimization techniques and the Python-C interface. My version was 60 times faster than the naive implementation for matrix operations.

Movie genre classifier

Python, Jupyter Notebooks

I used k-nearest neighbors to build a classifier that predicts a movies genre using the frequency of words in its screenplay with 80% accuracy

61CPU

Logism, RISC-V

I built a pipelined CPU from scratch in Logism. This included wiring up an arithmetic logic unit, a register file, a control logic unit, an immediate generator, and branch comparator. I then wrote and ran RISC-V code (an open standard instruction set architecture) on my CPU, fun stuff.
